moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. e4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Bb4 5. a3 Bxc3 6. dxc3 d6
comment:
Maybe Black
could have safely taken the pawn on e4 though this would cost him two tempi in
retreating the piece hence my reason for playing d6.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. e4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Bb4 5. a3 Bxc3 6. dxc3 d6 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bxf6 Qxf6 9. h3 Be6 10. Qd3 O-O-O
comment: Risky but worthwhile as Black has a lead in development.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. e4 Nc6 4. Nf3 Bb4 5. a3 Bxc3 6. dxc3 d6 7. Bg5 h6 8. Bxf6 Qxf6 9. h3 Be6 10. Qd3 O-O-O 11. Be2 Na5 12. Nd2 Nc6 13. b4 Ne7 14. O-O Ng6
comment:
An interesting position is
reached. White is trying for a Queenside attack whilst Black is trying for
play on the Kingside. However Black's pieces are supporting the attack whilst
White's are not and that is a crucial factor in what follows.
